name: Kepler-122
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-122 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-122 is a star with 1.454 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.22 times its radius. It is located 3452.62 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-122 is known to have 5 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-122 b

Kepler-122 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 5.77 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-122.

The mass of Kepler-122 b is 7.42 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-122 b is 2.34 that of Earth. At 7.42 Earth masses, Kepler-122 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-122 c

Kepler-122 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.11 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 12.47 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-122.

The mass of Kepler-122 c is 67.39 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-122 c is 5.87 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, Kepler-122 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.

Kepler-122 d

Kepler-122 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.15 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 21.59 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-122.

The mass of Kepler-122 d is 6.36 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-122 d is 2.2 that of Earth. At 6.36 Earth masses, Kepler-122 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-122 e

Kepler-122 e was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.23 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 37.99 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-122.

The mass of Kepler-122 e is 9.54 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-122 e is 2.6 that of Earth. At 9.54 Earth masses, Kepler-122 e is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-122, which contains 5 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
